newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - QMC says magnesia expansion on track.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - QMC says magnesia expansion on track.

text.p: Queensland Metals Corp Ltd said on Monday its wholly-owned Queensland Magnesia (QMAG) division's A$5.5 milion expansion project remained on budget and was ahead of its April 1997 scheduled start-up date.
"It appears that operational handover will occur in early 1997," QMC managing director Creagh O'Connor said in the group's September quarter report.

QMC, which paid Pancontinential Mining Ltd A$63 million earlier this year for the outstanding 40 percent stake in QMAG, has embarked on expansion of the project after raising a further A$112 million in a successful share issue and a further A$81.8 million from a recent rights issue.
Construction of two machine electronic ore sorting plants was well advanced with installation expected next month, O'Connor said.
A A$20 million expansion of the dead-burn plant's third shaft kiln had also started and was expected to be operational by the second half of next year, he said.
"It (the project) is on schedule and on budget," he said.
Negotiations had started to refinance the QMAG project debt on a basis consistent with the changed structure and outlook for the project, he said.
"It is expected that these negotiations would be completed by the end of the calendar year," O'Connor said.

Production output from QMAG was intentionally restrained during the September quarter, due mainly to slower activity in the market, exacerbated by the northern hemisphere summer and increased competition, O'Connor said.
Total ore mined fell to 666,750 tonnes from 787,395 in the corresponding quarter last year with 49,903 tonnes of beneficiated magnesite produced against 81,921 previously.
Total shipments of both electrofused and deadburned magnensia fell to 22,402 tonnes from 32,285 tonnes last year.
The QMAG project's production is used mainly in the production of magnesia-carbon bricks used as refractory linings in steel-making furnaces.
Meanwhile commercial negotiations were continuing to further a joint venture programme involving a large-scale demonstration plant for the group's Magmetal project, O'Connor said.
A full-scale commercial plant was estimated to cost about A$680 million with output targeted mainly at a rapidly-growing lightweight auto components industry, he said.
